key_insight: AndroidLens introduces a large-scale, bilingual benchmark of long-latency Android GUI tasks annotated with nested sub-targets, enabling fine-grained, stepwise evaluation of mobile GUI agents. This reveals agent performance on realistic multi-step workflows rather than coarse end-to-end success alone.
problem_solved: Existing GUI-agent benchmarks are limited to few apps, short/simple tasks, and coarse-grained metrics, which fail to measure agent capability on realistic long, multi-step mobile workflows and subgoal recovery.
method: Curate 571 long-latency tasks across Chinese and English environments, each averaging >26 steps to reflect realistic mobile workflows.
Annotate tasks with nested sub-targets to enable hierarchical, stepwise evaluation (subgoal success, intermediate recovery, end-to-end completion).
Provide a benchmarking protocol and fine-grained metrics (e.g., sub-target success rates, latency, error propagation) to evaluate robustness over long action sequences.
impact: AndroidLens gives researchers and practitioners a realistic, granular way to measure and improve GUI agents for complex mobile tasks, guiding progress on long-horizon planning, error recovery, and cross-lingual interface handling.
visual_elements: Flow diagram of a sample task showing nested sub-targets and the 26+ step sequence
Histogram or boxplot of task lengths (steps) and distribution across apps/languages
Metric dashboard mockup showing sub-target success rates, latency, failure modes, and end-to-end accuracy
Icon grid of representative apps and bilingual UI screenshots to highlight diversity
paper_title: AndroidLens: Long-latency Evaluation with Nested Sub-targets for Android GUI Agents
paper_authors: Yue Cao, Yingyao Wang, Pi Bu, Jingxuan Xing, Wei Jiang
